To communicate intention faster and more directly, <italic>Thunderclap</italic> makes several simplifications. Congressional acts combine category and year. Holding companies and corporations identified with “HC”. “MM” prefixes identify short-term liquid debt money markets. Names of people are not <italic>italicized</italic>, but <italic>firm</italic> names are and do not use definite articles. Some other institutional proper nouns are also <italic>italicized</italic>. Acronyms are generally not <italic>italicized</italic>. Descendancy is usually direct. Cousinhood is often of the first order, unless a surname, then usually implies several marriages between the surnamed families. Middle names are either maternal or maiden surnames. Some surnames have been changed for differentiation from others (e.g., Smith to Smyth).


Introduction [WIP]
<italic>Panics</italic>
The premise of <italic>Thunderclap</italic> is that to understand financial panics, one needs to examine their historical context. 
The terminology of panics is imprecise for various reasons. Robert Rubin, reflecting on his experience as Secretary of <italic>United States Treasury </italic>(“UST”) after co-chairing <italic>Goldman Sachs</italic>, said that “<italic>I avoided using words such as </italic><italic>‘</italic><italic>panic</italic><italic>’</italic><italic> and </italic><italic>‘</italic><italic>meltdown</italic><italic>’</italic><italic>, preferring less vivid terms such as </italic><italic>‘</italic><italic>contagion</italic><italic>’</italic><italic> and </italic><italic>‘</italic><italic>loss of confidence.</italic><italic>’</italic><italic> I</italic><italic>’</italic><italic>d learned while working in the White House as director of the National Economic Council (NEC) that the words public officials use can make an enormous difference, and that was even truer at the Treasury</italic>.” (). 
In the foundational work in quantitative economic history,  observe that: “<italic>In much of our literature, the preconceptions about variations in growth rates are obvious in the terminology. 19</italic><italic>th</italic><italic> </italic><italic>century economists spoke of panics and crises. Few people in the </italic><italic>‘</italic><italic>30s, however, wrote about the </italic><italic>‘</italic><italic>panic of 1929</italic><italic>’</italic><italic>; by then, the profession had learned that it was studying cycles. Since WWII we have changed our focus once again. We are concerned with the problems of development and sustained growth; we tend to look for </italic><italic>‘</italic><italic>breakthroughs</italic><italic>’</italic><italic>, </italic><italic>‘</italic><italic>takeoffs</italic><italic>’</italic><italic>, and </italic><italic>‘</italic><italic>big pushes.</italic><italic>’</italic>” Does this theory imply that ‘panics’ often occur alongside technological advancements and are of secondary importance to other government objectives? That is probably not the case.
There have always been and will always be panics in the financial markets. For example,  chronicles a 33 CE bankruptcy law that collapsed Rome’s money market, which had little to do with technological advance. Panics encompass a range of events, from bank crises to credit crunches, housing busts, and stock market crashes. While the economic cost of panics may increase debt defaults, unemployment, and tax defaults, the impact of economic crises varies. As credit and housing busts can extend recessions, bank panics may destabilize the political order. 
Given the lack of consensus available immediately on the cause of panics, politicians typically appeal to emotions, rather than facts. The allegories that grow out of panics are the main factors molding political and social systems. It is often easier to blame bankers and politicians. So, voter preferences shift to greater state control after panics. Though production drops are usually short-lived, the cycle of political extremism continues to reshape legislation for a considerably longer period.
Several of the seminal studies exploring the causes and consequences of panics include , , and . These works alternately attribute panics to monetary policy, banker greed, or market irrationality. One reason for this is that information about banks only becomes public and interesting enough for the media during panics.
But if bad or irrational business decisions are omnipresent, monetary policy is the central factor of panics for otherwise functional markets. According to Friedman in , “<italic>Inflation is everywhere and always a monetary phenomenon.</italic>” And again in , saying “<italic>the political establishment tried to prolong the happy glow by attributing the acceleration of inflation to special events—bad weather, food shortages, labor union intransigence, corporate greed, the OPEC cartel, or any straw at which they could grasp</italic>.” 
While monetary policy can contract economies to end inflation, panics often have different root causes. Under the gold standard, for example, central banks increased interest rates to prevent gold outflows following panics. Similarly, policies implemented after the initial panic can either exacerbate the crisis or redirect economic activity. These policy shifts are sensitive to disruption and contribute to a continuous regulatory cycle.
For its role in panics, monetary policy holds a unique place in democracy. To prevent political interference, most countries have established a separation between central bank monetary policy and executive government control. Few agencies can challenge the party in power as much as central banks. This differentiates credit from other public interests such as climate, health, and trade. Like coal regions support mining to increase low-skill jobs, high capital and low labor oil and gas investments cut prices. While scientists continue to debate whether hydro-carbons cause climate change or politics manufacture climate emergencies, private energy always competes on the political and social stage. 
While there have been numerous books written on the <italic>Panic of 2007</italic>, relatively few years have passed compared to when the <italic>Panic of 1929</italic> was covered by , , and . Surprisingly, most of the latter do not discuss law, energy policy, or any demographic or geographic factors. While Wigmore’s study on American securities markets in the four years from 1929 investigated industries, it was only for 6 out of 760 pages. Over six decades after the event, Wicker’s academic work was the first to identify bank failures with just three regions.
Unfortunately, much of the panic literature focuses on the effects and responses to panics without providing historical or legal context. Part of this has to do with how academia and publishers compartmentalize disciplines, fracturing our understanding of panics and society. But while policymakers use the <italic>law & economics</italic> approach to curb inflationary protectionism, economists often ignore the difficult-to-quantify law. 
Monetary policy seems to clearly have been to blame for the inflation of 1624. Speaking of Habsburg Spanish Emperor Philip IV, ) notes “<italic>In the first five years after his accession, the output was enormous. But, as has almost always happened in similar cases, the resultant monetary disorder was attributed to malfeasance, particularly by foreigners, rather than to defective monetary policy</italic>.” The ‘foreigners’ were mostly Jews and Protestants, such as the Dutch, who were at war with Spain. 
However, investigating economic crises across the Long 17th century,  challenge Earl Hamilton’s monetary policy theory of panics, which centered on silver prices and the inflow of American treasure through Eurasia to Japan. They propose a more comprehensive explanation for the global uprisings, delving into religious, labor, and climate shifts.
Likewise,  placed American post-WWII panics in relation to fiscal policy. However, he considered energy policy as exogenous to government policy and did not mention a single banker, union, anti-trust action, or minority. Are those factors negligible? <italic>Thunderclap </italic>argues otherwise. 
Furthermore, panic affects various geographies, asset classes, and industries in distinct ways. As ), Mexico’s Minister of Industry & Natural Resources, wrote on the twilight of his country’s sovereign debt default: “<italic>Capital markets work to a large extent by rationing credit, not simply through changes in interest rates in... smooth way[s]... If the debt ratios of a borrower exceed certain maximum limits, the country may not obtain the required finance whatever the level of the interest rate</italic>.” By tracing the impact of regulatory policies through a contextual, historical narrative, <italic>Thunderclap</italic> aims to portray panics in a fuller light.
<italic>Sociology</italic>
“<italic>So long as Isaac of York trusted his brother Jacob of Marseilles</italic>”, one historian wrote of Jews of the Middle Ages, “<italic>and both of them trusted their cousin Joseph of Jerusalem, all three stood to make a profit</italic>.” Like nepotism in private transactions, “<italic>crony capitalism</italic>” centralizes informal relationships in government dealings can ensure trust and align long term interests. 
But like fraudsters can exploit trust for greed or to conceal mistakes, so can politicians label informal arrangements as sinister and corrupt. Corruption is a natural result when panics follow policy actions under political bias. The customary understanding of corruption confines it within strict legal definitions, predominantly associating it with the state and public sectors, failing to recognize its broader entrenchment within cultural norms and its pervasive presence across both public and private domains (). 
As  argues, economic action is embedded in ongoing social networks, rather than being the product of atomized actors assumed by neoclassical economics. Trust, reciprocity, and reputation within these networks shape behavior, enabling cooperation but also creating potential for exclusion or corruption. Unlike new institutional economics, which treats institutions primarily as efficient solutions to economic problems, Granovetter emphasizes the historical and relational origins of institutions, showing how social structures constrain and direct economic action. 
Studying the Indonesian <italic>Panic of 1997</italic>,  demonstrates that nepotism and corruption are not inherently destabilizing; their impact depends on institutional quality. In strong regulatory and corporate environments, family and ethnic networks reinforced trust, whereas under weak institutions, the same networks could amplify dysfunction. 
In Japan, a similar interplay between kinship and capitalism persists through the traditional practice of <italic>mukoyoshi</italic>—the adoption of adult sons-in-law into family businesses. For centuries, Japanese conglomerate families have used this system to ensure capable succession and preserve family control. By selecting sons-in-law rather than relying solely on blood heirs, families can prioritize merit and leadership skills while maintaining lineage continuity. Listed Japanese companies led by adopted sons-in-law outperform both those managed by blood heirs and those run by unrelated executive between 1962 and 2000. Such nepotism functions less as favoritism than as a market mechanism to prevent dynastic stagnation—illustrating how family capitalism, when socially embedded and performance-driven, can enhance rather than undermine efficiency.
Elites play a significant role in policy making. Traditional perspectives often portray society as a hierarchical pyramid, presenting a straightforward structure with elites perched at the summit and the general populace relegated to the base. This oversimplification disregards the intricate interplay and dynamic nature of social relationships and networks (). 
As such relationships are often familial, conventional views similarly cast nepotism in a uniformly negative light, neglecting to acknowledge potential variations between beneficial and detrimental instances (). Indeed, Bellow emphasizes the continued prevalence in America of familial traditions and nepotism across different societal spheres such as the military, religious institutions, and labor unions.
Unlike the entertainment industry, where celebrities are widely recognized, few voters can readily name current or historical minority bankers and industrialists. “<italic>As Ferguson [</italic><italic>] warns in his introduction, it is hard to write about bankers and financiers. For all their importance, what they do on a day-to-day basis is rarely good raw material for drama except, of course, during crises like the one we have just lived through—and nothing dates faster or reads more dryly than financial coups of previous decades.</italic>” (). 
To avoid perpetuating stereotypes and potential political backlash, authors often omit discussions about the backgrounds of policymakers, financiers, and industrialists. Nevertheless, these omissions lead to incomplete accounts and may obscure the underlying historical context and policy decisions. A gender-focused perspective, for example, sheds light on the unique role of female bankers, differentiating performance from cultural and policy influences. Similarly, examining other minority lenses can enhance our understanding of economic developments, better prepare us for the future, and humanize minority capitalists as an alternative narrative to the rising anti-capitalist sentiments.
Granovetter’s view of economic activity as embedded in social networks points to banking as “<italic>the facilitation of economic trust</italic>.” Unlike regulatory definitions, which focus on formal operations, licenses, or legal status—and change across time and jurisdictions—such a trust-centered view captures the underlying function of banking: coordinating obligations, resources, and influence. Along with “bankers”, such a definition includes banking families, interlocking directors, and political authorities who perform the same relational role, even if they never sat in a bank. By focusing on trust rather than instruments or formal structures, one gains a broader, historically inclusive, and socially grounded understanding of banking and society.
Throughout history, religions have often bound dominant social groups to the land as serfs or, in regions without cattle, as slaves. In contrast, ‘minority middlemen’ diasporas, who remained non-conformist, consistently dominated commerce. For example, moneylenders, entertainers, and other roles perceived to be undesirable like have historically been filled by Jews, Christians, and Muslim in Christian, Muslim, and Hindu societies, respectively. But while the Scots, Quakers, and Huguenots had served as minority middlemen for England, they gradually assimilated into the aristocracy, leaving mainly Jews and Asians discriminated.
 noted that inequities are rarely the result of discrimination by dominant groups, noting the prevalence of middlemen bankers, including Greek and Armenians in Ottoman Turkey, Chinese in Malaysia, Germans in Brazil, Lebanese in West Africa, Italians in Argentina, Indians in East Africa, Scots in Britain, Ibos in Nigeria, and Marwaris in India. They maintained their distinct identities through endogamous marriage practices and established close-knit economic and nepotistic social networks that transcended political borders. On the other hand, a lens might produce a bias. By focusing on summarizing the numerous chronicles of great Jews, one might wrongly assume that there were no other competitors or that all Jews lived in the same way.
This socio-political marginalization frequently acted as a catalyst for innovation and notably enabled women, particularly widows, to participate in trade and finance. For most European women, this era of ‘equity’ persisted until the emergence of multinational banks and corporations in the 19th century, which limited family competition and excluded women from the business realm for a century. 
Simultaneously, industrialization accelerated the spread of bonded labor from Africa to Scotland, a point Karl Marx highlighted. Some of his disciples theorized that under Marxism, law would become obsolete. One of the challenges facing capitalism is its ability to resonate with diverse audiences. Some individuals, disillusioned with capitalism, may be drawn to the moralistic simplicity of socialism, while others may exploit the system for personal gain. 
The co-evolution of gender, race, and religion continues to play a pivotal role in shaping economies. Religious perspectives provide valuable insights into how family lineages historically financed development, often extending credit with guarantees during crises. To safeguard these lines of credit, empires frequently embraced ‘legal pluralism,’ which segregated laws based on geography, ethnicity, or trade. While this approach provided protection for certain groups, it could also expose them to violence, forcing minority communities into undignified trading activities. 
For centuries, the Emperors of Austria and Russia expelled Jews from specific cities, the approach was often reciprocal rather than competitive, promoting other cities to excel in complementary industries. However, even those under the protection of royal patrons with absolute powers, court bankers often faced expulsion or execution when their services were no longer required or death of their benefactors. In many cases, bankers chose public execution over abandoning their faith through conversion. Their lives were just part of their commitment to the public good, others including arranged marriage at young ages for communal benefit, often to distant places without divorce. 
As  observed, Jews had been <italic>“pushed into positions as businessmen and bankers almost by force… blocked from the civil service, the army, the judiciary, and the trades.”</italic> Excluded from traditional occupations, they “<italic>placed themselves in the holes and cleavages of the medieval order</italic>,” developing what he termed a “<italic>pioneer psychology</italic>.” 
Frankfurt and other German municipalities protected Jews and often enacted Primogeniture-type laws limited the ability to marry and own property to the eldest, perpetuating socio-economic marginalization within the Jewish community, and incentivizing migration. As Frankfurt restricted marriages to twelve a year, other discriminations against these Protected Jews included higher tax rates than Christians, social and economic exclusion and enclosure in a ghetto, while guilds and local laws limited their career options and pushed them into riskier moneylending and commerce.
The Jewish Torah links the preservation of lineage—<italic>yichus</italic>—to the substance of faith and transmission of divine teaching, making lineage the basis for the continued connection with God and limiting the Jewish priestly caste (Kohanim) to descendants of Aaron, Moses’ brother, who adopted surnames like Cohen, Kagan, Kahn, Kann, Caen, and Kaplan to denote their connection. The Levites, descendants of Moses’ tribe, supported the Kohanim and used surnames like Landau, Levin, Levi, Levy, Loewe, Epstein, Horowitz, and Segal. 
Focusing on Russian-speaking Jewish families,  compared careers between 1858 and 2001 for three surname groups: rabbinical, occupational, and all others. Even as surnames evolved, occupational biases had persisted for over two centuries. Individuals with rabbinical surnames exhibited a distinct inclination towards professions such as engineering and positions as head/chief officers, particularly in the earlier periods. In contrast, those with occupational surnames showed a consistent tendency to work as laborers. Despite these disparities, the individuals within these groups generally did not identify themselves as distinct, with many bearers of rabbinical surnames remaining unaware of their names’ historical connections to their professions.
Beyond the second generation, relationships between fathers and sons or between brothers often struggled. A notable exception is the Rothschild family, who first benefited the simultaneous presence of five brothers across five international financial centers. In the second generation, 14 out of 18 marriages occurred within the Rothschild family, followed by 13 out of 30 in the subsequent generation. According to another estimate, half of the Rothschild family’s 58 weddings were intermarriages over the 19th century were among family members, ensuring the continuation of their inheritance and lineage. 
Among <italic>Rothschild</italic>’s earliest agents, including <italic>Mendelssohn</italic> in Prussia and <italic>Frankel</italic> and <italic>Gunzburg</italic> in Russia, and <italic>Samuel Phillips</italic> in Brazil, <italic>Davidzon</italic> in San Francisco, <italic>Joseph</italic> in New York, <italic>Wagg</italic>, and <italic>d’W</italic><italic>orms</italic> of Ceylon were descendants and in-laws of the Katzenellenbogen (“Katz”) family. One of Judaism’s holiest dynasties, the Kohanim Katz claim descent from King David.  offers valuable this lineage. 
Unlike most descendances in Judaism, Katz-descendancy may be a maternal bloodline as even husbands from esteemed religious and banking families often adopted their wives’ Katz surnames. Moreover, not all Katz are Katzenellenbogen. Per , “<italic>Katz, also Cahn and Cohen, originally not the designation for a specific family, but the tribal designation for every priestly family (Katz = Cohen Zedek = the righteous priest), which is why, for example, the priestly families Gans, Spanier, Straus are also called Katz. However, the family that had the fixed family name Katz around 1800 can be traced back to the butcher (Kazef) Salomon Katz, who lived around 1710.</italic>”
“Katz” in this work usually refer to the major branches of the Katz family. Such descendancy has been ascertained using Neil Rosenstein or a link to Meir Katz, Maharam of Padua using genealogical website Geni.com. References that note uncertain lineage of Katz are possibly Koehn-Zadeks.) While the Katz lineage is well-documented, the strategic nature of their marriages and relationships is often overlooked without proper historical context.
Katz-descendants, aside from their financial acumen, also lent credibility to various ventures. For instance, in inter-war Germany, the founder of <italic>Danat</italic>, Jakob Goldsmith, initially faced rejection by a converted Jewish banker but later secured a contract with Ludwig Katz. However, a 1929 fraud scandal involving Ludwig raised questions about the ‘unlimited trust in management.’ While the Katz family’s influence waned after the Holocaust, some cousins, including <italic>Rothschild</italic>, <italic>Kuhn Loeb</italic> (“<italic>Kuhn</italic>”), and <italic>Lazard</italic>, continued shaping finance. 
The Katz also intermarried with families that were regionally powerful.  chronicles some of the many Judeo-French politicians and banking families who trace their descendance to four families of Protected Jews allowed to settle in Nancy following the <italic>Panic of 1720</italic>, including <italic>Rothschild</italic>, <italic>Lazard</italic>, and many others. 
Karl Marx—whose Katz-descendant father had converted to retain his government post—argued that Jewish financiers were essential backers of tyrants, especially in France, Austria, and Russia, portraying them in a conspiratorial, “Jews control the world” framework. In doing so, he largely ignored Christian bankers, converts, and the historical reality that tyrants exist independently of Jewish finance. At the same time, he maintained affectionate relationships with his converted elite relatives and admired the cultural accomplishments of the Heine and Mendelssohns families. 
His collaborator, Friedrich Engels, was heir to a wealthy Anglo-German Protestant mercantile-industrial ‘cousinhood’ centered in Cologne, analogous in its elite networks to the Jewish banking families. Decades later, heirs of this Cologne cousinhood helped finance Hitler’s National Socialist Party. Both Marxism and Nazism opposed unregulated free markets and sought centralized control over economic activity. Both movements mobilized state power to reshape society and, in practice, led to mass deaths—through famine, purges, or systematic genocide. 
More esteemed than Protected Jews were the Court Jews, particularly descendants of Imperial Court Jews of Habsburg Austria, Samuel Oppenheim and Samson Wertheim. Like <italic>New York Times</italic> wedding announcements and obituaries for America in the 20th century,  documents family histories from inscriptions in ornate Viennese graves. Although sources are generally scattered, a few compendia help highlight patters (such as ) and ).
While literate Jews have long compiled genealogies, endogamous marriages play a crucial role universally in building trust networks, shaping skills, and influencing preferential laws. Historical examples of this practice include the descendants of Confucius in China, upper and trading castes in Hindu India, and the descendants of the family of the Muslim Prophet Muhammad in Yemen. 
Religion tied together social, commercial, and political law. While Islam tolerated usury more than Christianity, it placed greater restrictions on female entrepreneurship compared to Hindu commercial castes. Although Hinduism promoted widows to commit suicide, Islam allowed remarriage. In Shia Islam, daughters could inherit without sons, while egalitarian Sunnis favored male cousins. While Jews, Christians, Japan, and Germany followed primogeniture, Islam, China, Russia, Vietnam, India, and France practiced partible inheritance. After centuries of development, revolution, and cultural cross-pollination, the attitudes of these societies to capitalism remain similar. 
From the Middle Ages through the 19th century, Christian moral teachings and social hierarchy shaped distrust toward profit-making and lending. Overtime, lending through merchant banking gained acceptance and status due to its ties to elite families and foreign finance.
For centuries, Arabian society was structured into distinct clans and castes, with nobility at the apex. Tribal leaders, known as sheikhs, maintained their elevated status by marrying their daughters to sheikhs of other tribes and only accepting marriages from noble families. This practice broke the customary standards of kin and tribal endogamy. Likewise, Polish Historian Marek Minakowski argues that most Poles of peasant descent are unlikely to have Jewish ancestors, as the two groups historically lived alongside rather than integrated with each other, especially due to cultural and legal barriers. Intermarriage was more plausible among the nobility or intelligentsia.
From Ottoman Turkey, across the Mediterranean, and in the leading cities of Europe,  traces the how the Rodocanachi and their banking cousinhood descended from the ancient kings of Armenia and Greek Byzantine Imperial Palaiologos family. Among Anglo-American financiers and other plutocrats, descent from Emperor Charlemagne appears so common in genealogical records that it can, in many cases, be reasonably assumed after a generation or two of prominence. Arguably more important is the ability to trace this ancestry than its existence. Along with aristocratic descendancy, non-conformist religion united bankers. 
In Britain, Quakers played a pivotal role in driving banking and industrialization during the <italic>Napoleonic Wars</italic>. Despite the subsequent success of American Quakers,  concludes that Boston replaced Philadelphia as America’s financial center. Notable figures in this transition were Jay Gould and John Morgan. One of Morgan’s ancestors, Reverend Thomas Hooker, founded Connecticut Colony. His granddaughter married James Pierpont, a descendant of Charlemagne, who became the Pastor of New Haven, Connecticut, and one of the three ministers who co-founded <italic>Yale</italic>. Their grandson began lawyering in the 1810s but ordained in the clergy. His daughter later married banker Junius Morgan, the grandson of a Unitarian minister.
Before John Davison Rockefeller founded <italic>Standard Oil</italic> (“OIL”), his third great-grandfather, Solomon Morgan Avery, a descendant of Charlemagne, was a grantee of Chiswick, New Hampshire, and a proprietor of <italic>Susquehanna Land Co</italic>, which settled the Wyoming Valley in Pennsylvania after America’s Revolution. While Solomon married the daughter of the Reverend of New Haven, her sister wed a Pierpont, the brother-in-law of Reverend Hooker’s second great-granddaughter. 
Solomon’s son inherited over 1,000 acres along Tunkhannock Creek and served as justice of the peace and colonel of militia. A daughter of Solomon’s other son married the great-grandson of Johann Rockefeller, who immigrated from Germany around 1723 and acquired large landholdings in New Jersey. It was thought that Solomon’s second great granduncle was John Morgan’s forefather, but this relationship may be more distant.
Morgan soon joined other Protestants to organize <italic>Bankers Trust</italic> in 1903. The driving force was Henry Pomeroy Davison, an extended cousin of the Avery family and John Davison Rockefeller. Born to a family of bankers and Presbyterian clergy. <italic>Bankers Trust</italic> became a ‘bankers’ bank,’ with a board comprised of 12 men from large New York commercial banks, four from out-of-town commercial banks, and three from investment banks. 
<italic>Bankers Trust</italic> was led President Edmund Converse, the grandson of a Congregationalist reverend, alongside directors including George Perkins of <italic>Morgan</italic>, James Blair of <italic>Blair</italic>, Barton Hepburn of <italic>Chase</italic> NB, William Porter of <italic>Chemical</italic> NB, Davison and Thomas Lamont of <italic>Liberty</italic> NB/<italic>First</italic> NB<italic> of New York</italic>, and <italic>First</italic> NB <italic>of New York</italic> director William Moore.<italic> </italic>
While Porter descended from Reverend Hooker, Moore descended from bankers and Reverend Hooker’s associate, Colonial Connecticut’s Governor John Webster. As Lamont was the son of a Scotch-Irish Methodist minister, Blair had a heritage spanning over six centuries in Scotland, engaged in preaching, teaching, and landownership in America. Davison soon hired Benjamin Strong, who descended from Elder John Strong, who migrated from England to Massachusetts in 1630 and became as a tanner and Puritan church elder. Benjamin Strong’s mother was born to an influential Presbyterian minister. As Hepburn descended from an old Scotch military family and served as Comptroller of the Currency, he soon hired Albert Wiggin, the son of a Unitarian reverend.
With Elder Strong as an ancestor, John Morgan descended from of a Unitarian minister and Reverend John Cotton, a descendant of Emperor Charlemagne. Morgan’s private bank partners (“<italic>Morgan</italic>”) operated as family units per . Relying on the support and alliances of the Puritan ‘Boston Brahmin’ community, <italic>Morgan</italic> did not add partners of Jewish heritage until several decades after WWII. Instead, Morgan’s most prominent partner—Anthony Drexel—had converted to Episcopalism from Catholicism.  
After becoming a <italic>Morgan</italic> a Partner, Edward Whitney recruited his nephews, George and Richard. When the <italic>Federal Reserve Act of 1913</italic> (“FA1913”) mandated bankers and brokers separate, George became a <italic>Morgan</italic> Partner, while Richard served as <italic>Morgan</italic>’s primary stockbroker. Although Morgan advocated a discretion as a family partnership, another <italic>Morgan</italic> Partner had an affair with his neighbor. When her husband found out, he killed the wife and committed suicide in 1915. However, media reports did not link <italic>Morgan</italic>. And when Richard Whitney became mired in scandal for pilfering from <italic>Morgan</italic> in the 1930s, George remained a <italic>Morgan</italic> Partner for many more years. 
While corporations have supplanted many traditional partnerships, familial bonds continue to underpin the worlds of banking and industry. In some cases, these relationships are intricately woven. For instance, after acquiring <italic>Kidder Peabody</italic> in Boston, Albert Gordon married Mary Rousmaniere in 1934. Her sister, Frances, wed Richard Storrs in 1938, who would later become the Head of securities at the premier law firm <italic>Sullivan Cromwell</italic>. In Britain, intermarriages between bankers and the aristocracy date back to before <italic>World War I</italic>, leading to a web of connections that extended across various institutions, including <italic>Bank of England</italic>, the Conservative party, the Foreign Office, merchant banks, industry, and the media.
Although family linkages used to be prominent, with weddings announced in newspapers, the growing sentiment against dynasties and oligarchs has fostered privacy. Privacy of even celebrities is now guarded. However, these interconnections and relationships persist, among long settled and new immigrant communities. The ‘bamboo’ network, which has connected Overseas Chinese across Southeast Asia for centuries, continues to link Chinese businesses. James Chao, who fled Chinese Communism to America, maintained a close friendship with his schoolmate Jiang Zemin, who later became the Chinese President in 1989. 
Chao’s <italic>Foremost Shipping</italic> utilized ships from Chinese state-owned shipyards with government financing to transport iron ore for state-owned steel makers. Meanwhile, his daughter, Elaine, married Republican Senator Mitch McConnell, serving as the Secretary of Labor in President Bush II’s cabinet in 2001 and becoming the first Asian American woman to hold the position. Jiang’s son Mianheng played a significant role in state-backed investment ventures, including collaborations with companies like <italic>Microsoft</italic> and <italic>Nokia</italic>. His other son, Alvin, helped create <italic>Boyu Capital</italic>, a private equity firm by 2011. McConnell eventually ascended to the role of Senate Republican Majority Leader by 2015.
The interplay of familial and business ties extends to various cultural and religious groups. Devout Jains Anshu and Ajit pursued complementary careers, with Ajit heading <italic>Berkshire Reinsurance</italic> and Anshu marketed derivatives before leading <italic>Deutsche Bank</italic>. The Sheik Banga family similarly followed a strategic trajectory, with Manvinder Banga leading <italic>Unilever</italic> before transitioning to a private equity firm, while his brother Ajay worked as a <italic>Citi</italic> executive before becoming the head of <italic>MasterCard</italic> in 2010. The family connections continued when Ajay’s daughter was hired by <italic>Facebook</italic>’s <italic>Instagram</italic> to lead monetization, and <italic>MasterCard</italic> formed partnerships with <italic>Goldman</italic> and <italic>Apple</italic> in retail banking ventures.
Hindu marriages are influenced by caste dynamics, and high-caste Indians have played prominent roles in leading global corporations such as <italic>Barclay, Citi, Google, Microsoft, Pepsi, IBM, Adobe, </italic>and<italic> McKinsey</italic>. Notably, by 2020, Kamala Harris, a half-Indian Brahmin, became President Biden’s VP as a Democrat.
